unit: Unit 6 | Inference for Categorical Data: Proportions
title: $p$-value Interpretation
question_text:
A study reported that the proportion of college students who experience heart palpitations after drinking an energy drink is $0.18$. The dean of a university believes that the proportion of students at his university who experience heart palpitations after drinking an energy drink is less than $0.18$. The dean randomly sampled students from the university who had just had an energy drink and found that $16\%$ of them had experienced heart palpitations.
All conditions for inference were met, and the $p$-value for the appropriate hypothesis test was $0.30$. Which of the following statements is the best interpretation of the $p$-value?
Which of the following statements is the best interpretation of the $p$-value?

choices.text: The probability that the alternative hypothesis is true is $0.30$.
The probability that the null hypothesis is true is $0.30$.
If the proportion of students who experience heart palpitations at the university is $18\%$, then the probability of observing results of at most $16\%$ is $0.30$.
If the proportion of students who experience heart palpitations at the university is $18\%$, then the probability of observing results of at least $16\%$ is $0.30$.
The probability of observing $16\%$ of students who experience heart palpitations at this university is $0.30$.

solution:
The definition of the $p$-value is the probability, assuming the null hypothesis is true, that the statistic would take a value as extreme or more extreme from the null hypothesis than the one actually observed.

By this definition, we can eliminate Choices 'A', 'B', and 'E'.

Deciding between Choices 'C' and 'D', let us refer to the hypotheses:

$$H_0: p = 0.18 $$

$$H_A: p < 0.18$$

The alternative hypothesis states the dean is trying to prove is less than $18\%$ of students who drink energy drinks at his university experience heart palpitations. The statistic he got when he gathered his data was $16\%$ and it yielded a $p$-value of $0.30$. This indicates if the null hypothesis were true, then observing results of at most $16\%$ would happen $30\%$ of the time.

The reason it is at most is that he is trying to prove that less than $18\%$ of students at his university experience heart palpitations. Based on the definition of the $p$-value, the values of the statistic would take a value as far or farther away from the value of the null hypothesis($18\%$) than the statistic in our sample($16\%$).

For example, $15\%$ is further away from our null hypothesis value of $18\%$ than $16\%$ is. However $17\%$ is not further away from $18\%$ than $16\%$ is.

Test-taking tip: in essence, whatever the inequality sign for the alternative is, that will indicate the way you want to describe $p$-value.

Explanation of Distractors

Choices 'A', 'B', and 'E' have already been eliminated.

Choice 'D' is incorrect because the $p$-value if it was at least $16\%$ would be $1-0.30=0.70$.
